snippet: A century later, the lessons from the carnage of World War I should be to reflect on the forces that led Europe sleepwalking to self-destruction.
abstract: Editorial notes that centenary of World War I has prompted desire among many nations to make sense of conflict and their role in it; says longing is more keen in post-Cold War world that has become more confusing and volatile; holds Europe and Russia's differing interpretations of their roles in conflict underscore inherent hazard of drawing parallels from history or assigning responsibility for war.
lead_paragraph: A century later, the lessons from the carnage of World War I should be to reflect on the forces that led Europe sleepwalking to self-destruction.
